author: Sophie Jamieson
title: Johnston Press confident in strategy despite slump in print revenue
text:
Media and Telecoms Johnston Press confident in strategy despite slump in print revenue Publisher of the Scotsman and the Yorkshire Post reports a rise in pre-tax profits but newspaper sales and advertising revenue were both down Chief executive Ashley Highfield said the business would "continue to target further cost savings" Comments 
Local newspaper group Johnston Press has announced a rise in pre-tax profits although revenue continues to decline with a slump in print advertising and newspaper sales. 
The company, which publishes The Scotsman and the Yorkshire Post, said pre-tax profits for the first half of the year had risen by £2.2m, an improvement following a fall of £6.3m in the same period in 2014. 
But underlying revenue was down 4.6pc to £128.9m. 
Print advertising revenue declined faster than in 2014, dropping by 9.5pc, while revenue from print sales also slumped 5.3pc. 
The group blamed a “slowdown in general trading” in the second quarter for a drop in total underlying advertising revenue of 5.1pc. 
The Yorkshire Post is one of the group's regional titles Photo: Newscast 
Last month the company released a trading update warning of falling revenues. Chief executive Ashley Highfield said at the time that the publishing house had suffered particularly around the general election when there was “a high degree of uncertainty in the wider market”. 
In July, Johnston Press said it expected first-half profits to be “marginally” below last year, when the group reported an underlying profit of £6.1m and a statutory loss of £6.3m, on a turnover of £135.8m. 
Mr Highfield reiterated on Tuesday that trading conditions had been challenging, but said local publishing was “not as volatile as national publishing”. He added that the group would continue to target cost savings. 
The outlook was better in the digital side of the business, where audience grew by more than 20pc to 19.9 million. Digital revenue grew 17.5pc, albeit from a low base of £14.1m. 
Johnston Press said it was entering the second half from a lower base than expected, but decline had slowed in July. 
“We believe in our strategy and are confident that our transformation projects will position the group well for the future,” the company said.
